Continual Release of Differentially Private Synthetic Data

Mark Bun Boston University Marco Gaboardi Boston University Marcel Neunhoeffer Boston University Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich Wanrong Zhang Harvard University
Abstract

Motivated by privacy concerns in long-term longitudinal studies in medical and social science research, we study the problem of continually releasing differentially private synthetic data. We introduce a model where, in every time step, each individual reports a new data element, and the goal of the synthesizer is to incrementally update a synthetic dataset to capture a rich class of statistical properties. We give continual synthetic data generation algorithms that preserve two basic types of queries: fixed time window queries and cumulative time queries. We show nearly tight upper bounds on the error rates of these algorithms and demonstrate their empirical performance on realistically sized datasets from the U.S. Census Bureau’s Survey of Income and Program Participation.

\@maketitle

1 Introduction

In a longitudinal study, research subjects are repeatedly observed over an extended period of time. Longitudinal studies are essential in medicine and public health, where they are used to establish risk factors for disease (indeed, the term “risk factor” itself comes from the influential Framingham Heart Study [KRK+61]); in developmental psychology to track physical, social, and emotional development through childhood and aging; and in economics to understand employment and income levels and their relation to education, family, and significant life events. Longitudinal designs can be advantageous over single-shot designs in that they provide insight into group and individual-level changes over time. This aspect of the British Doctors’ survey led to the first conclusive evidence of the link between smoking and lung cancer [DH56].

Nevertheless, longitudinal studies come with several important practical challenges, as well as complexity in devising sound statistical methodology. The challenge we address in this work is maintaining the privacy of research subjects. Specifically, we wish to understand when we can analyze data collected from a longitudinal study under the guarantees of differential privacy [DMNS06]. While most algorithmic research in differential privacy focuses on single-shot data analysis, alternative models are well-equipped to address privacy in longitudinal collections. For instance, in the continual observation model of Dwork, Naor, Pitassi, and Rothblum [DNPR10] and Chan, Shi, and Song [CSS11], individual data is presented to an algorithm in a streaming fashion, and the goal of the algorithm is to produce an estimate of one or more summary statistics of the data at every time step. “User-level” differential privacy in this model guarantees that this algorithm’s entire sequence of outputs is insensitive to changing any individual’s contribution, even if that individual’s data appears arbitrarily many times in the stream. Various problems have been studied in the continual observation model [MMNW11, JKT12, BFM+13, KPXP14, CMHM17, SLM+18, JRSS21, CR22, ABC22, EMM+23], primarily motivated by networking and internet monitoring applications with extremely long time horizons.

Meanwhile, longitudinal data analysis for health and social science research has several features not fully captured in existing work. These include:

Synthetic data.

Analysts of privacy-protected datasets often want access in the form of synthetic data (a.k.a. synthesized microdata), which are sets of individual records whose statistical properties are similar to those of the original dataset. Synthetic data is a requirement for some releases, e.g., the 2020 Census of Population and Housing tabulations. In general, synthetic data facilitates exploratory data analysis and the use of existing analysis pipelines.

Structured updates.

In each reporting period of a longitudinal study, each individual is asked the same set of questions, and an update only needs to be produced after all of the data for that period has been reported. In contrast, prior work (e.g., [GRST22]) considered individual data contributions that could be interleaved in an arbitrary order, and required updates after every contribution. The additional structure of longitudinal collections may be used to design more efficient algorithms.

Small samples.

Longitudinal studies are complex to plan and expensive to run, often resulting in relatively small sample sizes. This makes it especially important for differentially private solutions to exhibit reasonable accuracy for realistic dataset sizes and parameter settings.

To capture these goals, we propose the following specialization of the continual observation model to enable the continual release of differentially private synthetic data. Following the literature on single-shot private synthetic data generation [BCD+07, BLR08], let 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} be a data universe, let T𝑇T be a time horizon. In each of rounds t=1,…,T𝑡1…𝑇t=1,\dots,T, a synthetic data generation algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is given a vector of updates Dt=(x1t,…,xnt)∈𝒳nsuperscript𝐷𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑥1𝑡…superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑛𝑡superscript𝒳𝑛D^{t}=(x_{1}^{t},\dots,x_{n}^{t})\in\mathcal{X}^{n}, consisting of one update from each of n𝑛n individuals, and produces a synthetic data vector D^t=(x^1t,…,x^mt)∈𝒳msuperscript^𝐷𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝑥1𝑡…superscriptsubscript^𝑥𝑚𝑡superscript𝒳𝑚\hat{D}^{t}=(\hat{x}_{1}^{t},\dots,\hat{x}_{m}^{t})\in\mathcal{X}^{m}. (Note here that m𝑚m is possibly different from n𝑛n.) The algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} should be:

Differentially private.

𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} should be differentially private with respect to changing any individual’s entire sequence of updates (xi1,…,xiT)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖1…superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑇(x_{i}^{1},\dots,x_{i}^{T}). This is the same as user-level privacy in the continual observation model.

Accurate with respect to 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}.

For every t=1,…,T𝑡1…𝑇t=1,\dots,T and every query q∈𝒬t𝑞subscript𝒬𝑡q\in\mathcal{Q}_{t}, it should hold that q​(D^1,…,D^t)≈q​(D1,…,Dt).𝑞superscript^𝐷1…superscript^𝐷𝑡𝑞superscript𝐷1…superscript𝐷𝑡q(\hat{D}^{1},\dots,\hat{D}^{t})\approx q(D^{1},\dots,D^{t}). That is, the synthetic dataset produced up to time t𝑡t should be accurate with respect to the set of queries that are well-defined up to time t𝑡t.

A non-baseline.

A first attempt at continually generating private synthetic data might be to try recomputing a new synthetic dataset from scratch in every round. In each time step t𝑡t, one could apply a single-shot synthetic data generator to the portion of the dataset observed up to time t𝑡t that yields accurate answers with respect to 𝒬tsubscript𝒬𝑡\mathcal{Q}_{t}. Composition theorems for differential privacy show that the worst-case error incurred overall is roughly T𝑇\sqrt{T} times larger than the single-shot generator’s. Besides this automatic hit to accuracy, this algorithm has the weakness that the synthetic dataset produced at time t+1𝑡1t+1 may consist of entirely different records than that at time t𝑡t. This can create inconsistency between analyses conducted on the synthetic data after each of these time steps. In contrast, our problem specification requires synthetic individuals to persist over time and for the longitudinal synthetic data generator to update their records incrementally. This is challenging, as even at time step t=1𝑡1t=1, the synthetic data generator must prepare synthetic records (x^1t,…,x^mt)superscriptsubscript^𝑥1𝑡…superscriptsubscript^𝑥𝑚𝑡(\hat{x}_{1}^{t},\dots,\hat{x}_{m}^{t}) in anticipation of all future queries and arbitrary future data records, as it cannot go back and change these values once they are released. Our consistency requirement is not only natural from the standpoint of using the synthetic data but as we shall see below, this way of thinking about the problem helps us design algorithms whose accuracy does not need to incur a poly⁡(T)poly𝑇\operatorname{poly}(T) overhead over the single-shot case.

Our results.

We study the continual private synthetic data generation problem for two fundamental classes of queries. We give theoretical error guarantees (essentially matched by lower bounds) and experimental evidence suggesting that they permit reasonable accuracy for social science datasets. A motivating case study for both the theoretical models and experiments in this paper is the US Census Bureau’s Survey of Income and Program Participation (SIPP) [Bur21]. The SIPP conducts monthly interviews of individuals to track income, employment, family composition, and participation in food and unemployment assistance programs. The problem of generating synthetic data for SIPP was previously considered in [BSA13, BCE18], but without the formal protections of differential privacy.

The two classes of queries we consider are counting queries, which are determined by a predicate q:𝒳t→{0,1}:𝑞→superscript𝒳𝑡01q:\mathcal{X}^{t}\to\{0,1\} and ask what fraction of the dataset satisfy q𝑞q. That is, such a predicate extends to a query defined over entire datasets D=(D1,…,Dt)𝐷superscript𝐷1…superscript𝐷𝑡D=(D^{1},\dots,D^{t}) where Di∈𝒳nsuperscript𝐷𝑖superscript𝒳𝑛D^{i}\in\mathcal{X}^{n} by taking q​(D1,…,Dt)=1n​∑i=1nq​(xi1,…,xit)𝑞superscript𝐷1…superscript𝐷𝑡1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝑞superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖1…superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡q(D^{1},\dots,D^{t})=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}q(x_{i}^{1},\dots,x_{i}^{t}). For simplicity and clarity, we take 𝒳={0,1}𝒳01\mathcal{X}=\{0,1\} for the classes of queries we consider. That is, each individual contributes a new bit of data in each reporting period. The problems and solutions we develop have natural extensions to handle categorical data.

Fixed time window queries.

Suppose we explore the incidence of various short-term phenomena in the data. For instance, for some parameter k𝑘k, we may be interested in understanding what fraction of the population was below the poverty line in each consecutive window of k𝑘k months and tracking how this incidence changes in response to historical events (such as broader economic downturns). We study the class of queries for which accuracy captures the following condition: When restricted to every time window of width k𝑘k (for every t≥k𝑡𝑘t\geq k), the histogram of the synthetic data approximates the corresponding histogram on the original dataset. That is, for every pattern s∈{0,1}k𝑠superscript01𝑘s\in\{0,1\}^{k} and every time step t𝑡t, the fraction of synthetic individuals for whom (x^it−k+1,…,x^it)=ssuperscriptsubscript^𝑥𝑖𝑡𝑘1…superscriptsubscript^𝑥𝑖𝑡𝑠(\hat{x}_{i}^{t-k+1},\dots,\hat{x}_{i}^{t})=s approximates the fraction of original dataset members for whom (xit−k+1,…,xit)=ssuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡𝑘1…superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡𝑠(x_{i}^{t-k+1},\dots,x_{i}^{t})=s.

We give an algorithm for this problem that guarantees concentrated differential privacy (CDP) [DR16, BS16], such that the worst-case error for any histogram bin is O~​(2k​T/n)~𝑂superscript2𝑘𝑇𝑛\widetilde{O}(2^{k}\sqrt{T}/n).111Note that this corrects an error in the submission version, where we stated a bound of O~​(k​T/n)~𝑂𝑘𝑇𝑛\widetilde{O}(\sqrt{kT}/n). Furthermore, we give a simple method by which an analyst can postprocess the generated synthetic data to obtain estimates with significantly less bias and error only O~​(k​T/n)~𝑂𝑘𝑇𝑛\widetilde{O}(\sqrt{kT}/n). For constant k𝑘k, these results essentially match a lower bound of Ω​(T/n)Ω𝑇𝑛\Omega(\sqrt{T}/n) that holds even for the single-shot problem of releasing accurate answers with respect to 𝒬Tsubscript𝒬𝑇\mathcal{Q}_{T} when the entire dataset is revealed [BS16]. Moreover, accuracy for histogram bins immediately implies accuracy for arbitrary queries defined over contiguous time windows of length k𝑘k. If a query q𝑞q can be written as a linear combination q​(xt−k+1,…,xt)=∑s∈{0,1}kws​𝕀​((xt−k+1,…,xt)=s)𝑞superscript𝑥𝑡𝑘1…superscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑠superscript01𝑘subscript𝑤𝑠𝕀superscript𝑥𝑡𝑘1…superscript𝑥𝑡𝑠q(x^{t-k+1},\dots,x^{t})=\sum_{s\in\{0,1\}^{k}}w_{s}\mathbb{I}((x^{t-k+1},\dots,x^{t})=s), then the synthetic data has error O~​(2k​‖w‖2​T/n)~𝑂superscript2𝑘subscriptnorm𝑤2𝑇𝑛\tilde{O}(2^{k}\|w\|_{2}\sqrt{T}/n) with respect to q𝑞q.

Cumulative time queries.

In addition to understanding phenomena over fixed time windows, we may also be interested in tracking longer-term trends over individual’s bitstrings. When 𝒳={0,1}𝒳01\mathcal{X}=\{0,1\}, a natural statistic to keep track of is the Hamming weight (cumulative number of 1’s) of individuals’ histories. This, for instance, enables tracking, for every time step t𝑡t and every value b𝑏b, the fraction of individuals who have been below the poverty line for at least b𝑏b out of the first t𝑡t months. We give a CDP algorithm for this problem with worst-case error O~​(T/n)~𝑂𝑇𝑛\tilde{O}(\sqrt{T}/n), which nearly matches a lower bound of Ω​(T/n)Ω𝑇𝑛\Omega(\sqrt{T}/n) that again holds even for the final single-shot problem.

Our algorithms for both problems follow a natural two-stage approach. For each time step t𝑡t, in the first stage, we privately compute noisy estimates for the new queries in 𝒬tsubscript𝒬𝑡\mathcal{Q}_{t}. In the second stage, we identify updates to the synthetic data that make it approximately consistent with these noisy statistics. For both problems we consider, the first stage is straightforward from standard techniques from the differential privacy literature: Independent noise addition to producing noisy histograms in the case of fixed time window queries and an adaptation of the classic tree-based aggregation mechanism [DNPR10, CSS11] for cumulative time queries.

The second stage, in each case, requires additional ideas. For the fixed time window problem, our ability to generate synthetic bits that will fit the new noisy statistics requires us to post-process these statistics so that they meet the following consistency constraints: For every z∈{0,1}k−1𝑧superscript01𝑘1z\in\{0,1\}^{k-1}, we have pz​0t+pz​1t=p0​zt−1+p1​zt−1superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑧0𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑧1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑝0𝑧𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑝1𝑧𝑡1p_{z0}^{t}+p_{z1}^{t}=p_{0z}^{t-1}+p_{1z}^{t-1}, where pstsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠𝑡p_{s}^{t} denotes the number of synthetic records that end in the substring s𝑠s at time t𝑡t. That is, the number of synthetic records ending with the suffix z𝑧z at time t−1𝑡1t-1 must be identical to the number of synthetic records ending with either z​0𝑧0z0 or z​1𝑧1z1 at time t𝑡t.

We solve this set of consistency constraints such that the error on each histogram bin can be written as a certain linear combination of errors of the noisy statistics generated in stage 1. We can then leverage the independence of these errors to give a sharp bound on the post-processed errors.

Another issue in synthetic data generation is the possibility that noisy histogram bin counts may go negative.

Naïvely clamping counts to be nonnegative does not work, as we cannot resurrect nonzero counts from zero counts at subsequent time steps. We overcome this issue by padding the initial synthetic dataset so that every histogram bin is well-represented. With high probability over the entire run of the algorithm, no noisy counts will ever go negative to cancel out the padding completely. Note that while the padding introduces bias into the estimates of each histogram bin, the amount of this bias is public information and can be corrected in additional post-processing if the analyst chooses to do so. Generating the next round of synthetic bits is somewhat simpler for cumulative time queries. But its feasibility relies on the statistics computed in stage 1 to satisfy the following two monotonicity constraints: For every value of b𝑏b and t𝑡t, the estimated count of individuals whose data has Hamming weight at least b𝑏b by time t𝑡t must be (1) at least the estimate produced for weight ≥babsent𝑏\geq b at time step t−1𝑡1t-1 and (2) at most the estimate produced for weight ≥b−1absent𝑏1\geq b-1 at time step t−1𝑡1t-1. The first condition corresponds to the fact that (synthetic) individuals’ Hamming weights can only increase over time. The second corresponds to the fact that Hamming weights can only increase by at most 111 each time step. Neither condition is automatically guaranteed by the tree-based aggregation mechanism but can be ensured by an additional monotonization procedure that adapts a technique from [CSS11] for ensuring the monotonicity condition (1).

1.1 Related work

While, to our knowledge, the problem of differentially private longitudinal synthetic data generation has yet to be studied, solutions to related questions have previously appeared in the differential privacy literature. Motivated by the problem of counting distinct elements in data streams, Ghazi, Kumar, Manurangsi, and Nelson [GKMN22] studied variants of our cumulative time queries problem. In their terminology, our cumulative time queries problem corresponds to answering CountOcc≥bsuperscriptCountOccabsent𝑏\mathrm{CountOcc}^{\geq b} queries, for all b𝑏b simultaneously, in their cumulative, item-level DP, bundle setting. Our solution also immediately implies an O~​(T/n)~𝑂𝑇𝑛\tilde{O}(\sqrt{T}/n)-error algorithm for answering CountOcc=bsuperscriptCountOccabsent𝑏\mathrm{CountOcc}^{=b} queries for all b𝑏b simultaneously in their time window, item-level DP, bundle setting that follows from the fact that the number of individuals producing bit 111 exactly b𝑏b times between time steps t1<t2subscript𝑡1subscript𝑡2t_{1}<t_{2} can be expressed as the difference between the number of individuals with Hamming weight at least b𝑏b up to time t2subscript𝑡2t_{2} and the number of individuals with Hamming weight at least b−1𝑏1b-1 up to time t1subscript𝑡1t_{1}. Using similar constructions to ours (and also building on a prior reduction of [BFM+13]), [GKMN22] studied these and related problems when the goal is to answer queries for any fixed single value of b𝑏b. Our algorithm simultaneously permits accurate estimation of these queries for all b𝑏b while also incrementally generating synthetic data matching these query answers.

Complementing work in the central model, there has also been extensive work on longitudinal data release under the stronger constraint of local differential privacy. Google’s RAPPOR system [EPK14] enables tracking the population-level average of a single Boolean statistic (corresponding to our fixed time windows problem with k=1𝑘1k=1) under a heuristic assumption that each individual’s bit flips its value only a small number of times. These ideas were developed further by [EFM+19], who gave an algorithm with error that scales with an upper bound on the number of times any individual’s bit can flip its value rather than the overall time horizon. And while it is not posed as a synthetic data generation problem, the task of incrementally generating synthetic data from their noisy estimates is immediate when k=1𝑘1k=1. [JRUW18] studied a similar problem, but in a model where it is further assumed that individuals come from distinct subpopulations, and in each time step, each individual independently draws a fresh bit from their subpopulation-specific distribution. Additional work on continual frequency estimation in the local model includes [DKY17, OWW22, XYH+22, APPG22].

For simplicity, we implement our algorithm for synthetic data release with respect to cumulative time queries using the classic binary tree counter. But it could be implemented using an arbitrary differentially private algorithm for tracking the sum of a stream of bits. Our formal description of Algorithm 3 is indeed stated in terms of a generic stream counter algorithm. Stream counters enjoying improved concrete accuracy guarantees have been the focus of recent attention [Hon15, DMR+22, FHU22, HUU23], and using them in place of the tree counter in our work may yield improved experimental results.

1.2 Limitations

Synthetic data can enable analysts to answer supported queries without prior knowledge and without modifying their analysis pipelines. This is the main reason behind the demand for tabular synthetic data and why it is a legal requirement for certain data releases. Nevertheless, it is understood to be intrinsically less accurate or efficient to generate compared to noisy query answers. It is important to acknowledge that synthetic data may not always match the accuracy of DP query answers that can be released through some other data structure [AACM+21].

Synthetic data is also intrinsically limited in the scope of analyses it permits. Our work identifies restricted but expressive classes of queries that permit accurate synthetic data generation algorithms. This approach aligns with the existing literature on DP single-shot synthetic data release, which provides theoretical accuracy guarantees for specific query classes. We envision restricted synthetic data as just part of a larger privacy-preserving data access system, where after performing initial exploratory data analysis on synthetic data, analysts may then decide to go through additional approvals to access the original data or to more accurate estimates.

Note also that even in the single-shot case, releasing synthetic data that preserves answers to specific queries can be computationally hard. For instance, preserving answers to 2-way marginal queries, a seemingly mild extension of the fixed time window queries considered in this paper, for k=2𝑘2k=2,222Specifically, the class of 2-way marginals consists of all queries of the form qi,j​(x1,…,xT)=xi∧xjsubscript𝑞𝑖𝑗superscript𝑥1…superscript𝑥𝑇superscript𝑥𝑖superscript𝑥𝑗q_{i,j}(x^{1},\dots,x^{T})=x^{i}\land x^{j}. Fixed time window queries for k=2𝑘2k=2 enable answering all such queries that take the form qi,i+1subscript𝑞𝑖𝑖1q_{i,i+1}. is computationally intractable [UV11] for worst-case data, under standard cryptographic assumptions.

2 Preliminaries

2.1 Continual synthetic data

Let 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} be a data universe and T𝑇T be a known time horizon. The data of an individual xi=(xi1,…,xiT)subscript𝑥𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖1…superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑇x_{i}=(x_{i}^{1},\dots,x_{i}^{T}) is a sequence of universe items where each xit∈𝒳superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡𝒳x_{i}^{t}\in\mathcal{X} is the report arriving at time t𝑡t. For a dataset of n𝑛n individuals, let Dt=(x1t,…,xnt)superscript𝐷𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑥1𝑡…superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑛𝑡D^{t}=(x_{1}^{t},\dots,x_{n}^{t}) be the vector of data reported at time t𝑡t. The entire dataset may thus be written as D=(D1,…,DT)𝐷superscript𝐷1…superscript𝐷𝑇D=(D^{1},\dots,D^{T}). For simplicity throughout the rest of this paper, we will take 𝒳={0,1}𝒳01\mathcal{X}=\{0,1\} unless otherwise stated. We are interested in releasing synthetic data that is accurate with respect to a class of queries 𝒬=∪t=1T𝒬t𝒬superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscript𝒬𝑡\mathcal{Q}=\cup_{t=1}^{T}\mathcal{Q}_{t}, where each 𝒬tsubscript𝒬𝑡\mathcal{Q}_{t} is a set of queries of the form q:(𝒳t)∗→ℝ:𝑞→superscriptsuperscript𝒳𝑡ℝq:(\mathcal{X}^{t})^{*}\to\mathbb{R} that are defined on prefixes of length t𝑡t.

Continual release of synthetic data.

The goal of a synthetic data generation algorithm is as follows. In each round t𝑡t, it receives as input a vector of reports Dt=(x1t,…,xnt)superscript𝐷𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑥1𝑡…superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑛𝑡D^{t}=(x_{1}^{t},\dots,x_{n}^{t}). It then produces a synthetic vector of reports D^t=(x^1t,…,x^mt)superscript^𝐷𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝑥1𝑡…superscriptsubscript^𝑥𝑚𝑡\hat{D}^{t}=(\hat{x}_{1}^{t},\dots,\hat{x}_{m}^{t}). For parameters α,β∈(0,1)𝛼𝛽01\alpha,\beta\in(0,1), we say that the synthetic data generation algorithm is (α,β)𝛼𝛽(\alpha,\beta)-accurate with respect to 𝒬=∪t=1T𝒬t𝒬superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscript𝒬𝑡\mathcal{Q}=\cup_{t=1}^{T}\mathcal{Q}_{t} if, for every input dataset D𝐷D, with probability at least 1−β1𝛽1-\beta over the coin tosses of the algorithm, it holds that for every t=1,…,T𝑡1…𝑇t=1,\dots,T and q∈𝒬t𝑞subscript𝒬𝑡q\in\mathcal{Q}_{t}, |q​(D1,…,Dt)−q​(D^1,…,D^t)|≤α.𝑞superscript𝐷1…superscript𝐷𝑡𝑞superscript^𝐷1…superscript^𝐷𝑡𝛼|q(D^{1},\dots,D^{t})-q(\hat{D}^{1},\dots,\hat{D}^{t})|\leq\alpha.

In this work, we focus on releasing synthetic data for two basic classes of counting queries. A counting query is specified by a predicate q:𝒳t→{0,1}:𝑞→superscript𝒳𝑡01q:\mathcal{X}^{t}\to\{0,1\}, for some 1≤t≤T1𝑡𝑇1\leq t\leq T, and extends to an entire dataset by averaging: q​(D1,…,Dt)=1n​∑i=1nq​(xi1,…,xit)𝑞superscript𝐷1…superscript𝐷𝑡1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝑞superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖1…superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡q(D^{1},\dots,D^{t})=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}q(x_{i}^{1},\dots,x_{i}^{t}). The classes of queries we study are:

Fixed time window queries.

Fix a parameter k∈{1,…,T}𝑘1…𝑇k\in\{1,\dots,T\}. For each string s∈{0,1}k𝑠superscript01𝑘s\in\{0,1\}^{k}, and each t=k,k+1,…,T𝑡𝑘𝑘1…𝑇t=k,k+1,\dots,T, define the query qst​(x1,…,xt)=𝕀​((xt−k+1,…,xt)=s)superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑠𝑡superscript𝑥1…superscript𝑥𝑡𝕀superscript𝑥𝑡𝑘1…superscript𝑥𝑡𝑠q_{s}^{t}(x^{1},\dots,x^{t})=\mathbb{I}((x^{t-k+1},\dots,x^{t})=s). The query qstsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑠𝑡q_{s}^{t} indicates whether the length-k𝑘k suffix of data item x𝑥x that has arrived by time t𝑡t equals s𝑠s. For each t𝑡t, the set of queries {qst}s∈{0,1}ksubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑠𝑡𝑠superscript01𝑘\{q_{s}^{t}\}_{s\in\{0,1\}^{k}} jointly capture this histogram of k𝑘k-bit suffixes of the portion of the data that has arrived by time t𝑡t.

Cumulative time queries.

For each b=0,1,…,T𝑏01…𝑇b=0,1,\dots,T and each t=1,…,T𝑡1…𝑇t=1,\dots,T, define the query
cbt​(x1,…,xt)=𝕀​(x1+⋯+xt≥b)superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑏𝑡superscript𝑥1…superscript𝑥𝑡𝕀superscript𝑥1⋯superscript𝑥𝑡𝑏c_{b}^{t}(x^{1},\dots,x^{t})=\mathbb{I}(x^{1}+\dots+x^{t}\geq b). That is, cbtsuperscriptsubscript𝑐𝑏𝑡c_{b}^{t} indicates whether the portion of data item x𝑥x that has arrived by time t𝑡t has Hamming weight at least b𝑏b.

Reducing cumulative time queries to fixed time window queries.

If we set k=T𝑘𝑇k=T, observe that each query cbtsuperscriptsubscript𝑐𝑏𝑡c_{b}^{t} may be written as cbt​(x)=∑s∈{0,1}k:|s|≥bqst​(x)superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑏𝑡𝑥subscript:𝑠superscript01𝑘𝑠𝑏superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑠𝑡𝑥c_{b}^{t}(x)=\sum_{s\in\{0,1\}^{k}:|s|\geq b}q_{s}^{t}(x). (Here, we are adopting the convention that each xit=0superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡0x_{i}^{t}=0 for t≤0𝑡0t\leq 0.) This implies that an accurate synthetic data generator for fixed time window queries with k=T𝑘𝑇k=T implies one for the cumulative time queries problem with a roughly 2ksuperscript2𝑘2^{k}-factor blowup in error. While this shows that the problems are related, our algorithm which is tailored to cumulative time queries achieves significantly better accuracy.

2.2 Differential privacy background

Differential privacy is a mathematical notion of privacy for statistical data analysis which bounds the amount of information an adversary can learn about any individual. Given a space of datasets 𝒳Tsuperscript𝒳𝑇\mathcal{X}^{T}, we say that two datasets D,D′𝐷superscript𝐷′D,D^{\prime} are neighboring if they differ in one individual’s information.

Definition 2.1 (Differential Privacy [DMNS06, DKM+06]).

A randomized algorithm ℳ:𝒳T→ℛ:ℳ→superscript𝒳𝑇ℛ\mathcal{M}:\mathcal{X}^{T}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} is (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-differentially private if for every pair of neighboring datasets D,D′∈𝒳T𝐷superscript𝐷′superscript𝒳𝑇D,D^{\prime}\in\mathcal{X}^{T}, and for every subset of possible outputs 𝒮⊆ℛ𝒮ℛ\mathcal{S}\subseteq\mathcal{R},

Pr⁡[ℳ​(D)∈𝒮]≤eε⋅Pr⁡[ℳ​(D′)∈𝒮]+δ.Prℳ𝐷𝒮⋅superscript𝑒𝜀Prℳsuperscript𝐷′𝒮𝛿\Pr[\mathcal{M}(D)\in\mathcal{S}]\leq e^{\varepsilon}\cdot\Pr[\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime})\in\mathcal{S}]+\delta.

Zero-concentrated differential privacy (zCDP) [DR16, BS16] is a variant of differential privacy that quantifies the closeness of distributions differently, and is especially amenable to analyzing Gaussian noise addition.

Definition 2.2 (Zero-Concentrated Differential Privacy (zCDP) [BS16]).

A randomized algorithm ℳ:𝒳T→ℛ:ℳ→superscript𝒳𝑇ℛ\mathcal{M}:\mathcal{X}^{T}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} is ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP if for every pair of neighboring datasets D,D′∈𝒳T𝐷superscript𝐷′superscript𝒳𝑇D,D^{\prime}\in\mathcal{X}^{T}, and for all α∈(1,∞)𝛼1\alpha\in(1,\infty), Dα(ℳ(D)||ℳ(D′))≤ρα,\mathrm{D}_{\alpha}(\mathcal{M}(D)||\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime}))\leq\rho\alpha, where DαsubscriptD𝛼\mathrm{D}_{\alpha} denotes the Rényi divergence of order α𝛼\alpha.

A ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP guarantee can be translated to a (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP guarantee using the following result from [BS16]: If ℳℳ\mathcal{M} provides ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP, then ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is (ρ+2​ρ​log⁡(1δ),δ)𝜌2𝜌1𝛿𝛿(\rho+2\sqrt{\rho\log(\frac{1}{\delta})},\delta)-differentially private for every δ>0𝛿0\delta>0. Zero-concentrated differential privacy is also desirable for its straightforward and tight composition, which characterizes how privacy degrades as performing more computations on the data.

Theorem 2.1 (zCDP Composition).

Let ℳ1:𝒳T→ℛ:subscriptℳ1→superscript𝒳𝑇ℛ\mathcal{M}_{1}:\mathcal{X}^{T}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} is ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP and ℳ2:𝒳T→ℛ:subscriptℳ2→superscript𝒳𝑇ℛ\mathcal{M}_{2}:\mathcal{X}^{T}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} is ρ′superscript𝜌′\rho^{\prime}-zCDP, then the mechanism defined as (ℳ1,ℳ2)subscriptℳ1subscriptℳ2(\mathcal{M}_{1},\mathcal{M}_{2}) satisfies (ρ+ρ′)𝜌superscript𝜌′(\rho+\rho^{\prime})-zCDP.

The discrete Gaussian mechanism [CKS20] with parameter σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} takes in a function q𝑞q, dataset D𝐷D, and outputs q​(D)+𝒩ℤ​(0,σ2)𝑞𝐷subscript𝒩ℤ0superscript𝜎2q(D)+\mathcal{N}_{\mathbb{Z}}(0,\sigma^{2}). The noise scale is fully specified as σ2=Δ​q2​ρsuperscript𝜎2Δ𝑞2𝜌\sigma^{2}=\frac{\Delta q}{2\rho}, given the privacy parameter ρ𝜌\rho and the query sensitivity Δ​qΔ𝑞\Delta q. The variance of 𝒩ℤ​(0,σ2)subscript𝒩ℤ0superscript𝜎2\mathcal{N}_{\mathbb{Z}}(0,\sigma^{2}) is at most σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}.

Definition 2.3 (Discrete Gaussian [CKS20]).

The discrete Gaussian distribution with mean 00 and scale σ𝜎\sigma is denoted 𝒩ℤ​(0,σ2)subscript𝒩ℤ0superscript𝜎2\mathcal{N}_{\mathbb{Z}}(0,\sigma^{2}). It is a probability distribution supported on the integers and defined by Pr⁡[X=x]=exp⁡(−x22​σ2)∑y∈ℤexp⁡(−y22​σ2).Pr𝑋𝑥superscript𝑥22superscript𝜎2subscript𝑦ℤsuperscript𝑦22superscript𝜎2\Pr[X=x]=\frac{\exp(-\frac{x^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}})}{\sum_{y\in\mathbb{Z}}\exp(-\frac{y^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}})}.

3 Generating Synthetic Data for Fixed Time Window Queries

In this section, we consider fixed time window queries. The goal is to produce differentially private synthetic data such that the histogram of the synthetic data approximates the corresponding histogram on the original dataset for every time window of width k𝑘k.

3.1 Algorithm

This section presents our algorithm for generating differentially private synthetic data that preserves the histogram over every fixed window of length k𝑘k. Our algorithm consists of two phases at each step. The first phase is to compute the noisy private statistics about the data in the most recent length-k𝑘k window. The second phase is to construct synthetic data according to the noisy statistics. We elaborate on the details of each phase below.

Producing noisy statistics.

At each update step of the algorithm, i.e., time steps t=k,k+1,…,T𝑡𝑘𝑘1…𝑇t=k,k+1,\ldots,T, we represent (Dt−k+1,…,Dt)superscript𝐷𝑡𝑘1…superscript𝐷𝑡(D^{t-k+1},\dots,D^{t}) as a histogram with a bin for each string of length k𝑘k, and the value of each bin is the number of appearances of that string in this segment of the dataset. Our algorithm eventually runs for a total of T−k+1𝑇𝑘1T-k+1 update steps. So to privatize the statistics, we construct a DP histogram by independently adding discrete Gaussian noise to each bin: C^st=Cst+npad+𝒩ℤ​(0,T−k+12​ρ)subscriptsuperscript^𝐶𝑡𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝐶𝑡𝑠subscript𝑛padsubscript𝒩ℤ0𝑇𝑘12𝜌\hat{C}^{t}_{s}=C^{t}_{s}+n_{\text{pad}}+\mathcal{N}_{\mathbb{Z}}(0,\frac{T-k+1}{2\rho}), where npadsubscript𝑛padn_{\text{pad}} is a padding parameter we will discuss later.

Generating synthetic data.

At time t=k𝑡𝑘t=k, we initialize the synthetic dataset to be any dataset such that its histogram representation is consistent with the DP histogram at time t=k𝑡𝑘t=k. For t>k𝑡𝑘t>k, when we move a sliding window from time t𝑡t to time t+1𝑡1t+1, the two windows overlap on a segment of length k−1𝑘1k-1. Given any overlapping segment z∈{0,1}k−1𝑧superscript01𝑘1z\in\{0,1\}^{k-1}, synthetic data ending in suffix z​0𝑧0z0 or z​1𝑧1z1 at time t+1𝑡1t+1 must arise by extending synthetic data ending in suffix 0​z0𝑧0z or 1​z1𝑧1z at the previous time t𝑡t. That is, the synthetic data we generate to approximately fit the new noisy counts C^ssubscript^𝐶𝑠\hat{C}_{s} must be consistent with this overlapping region. More precisely, let pstsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑠p^{t}_{s} denote the number of appearances of suffix s𝑠s in the synthetic data in the window of time t𝑡t. Then the synthetic data histogram at t+1𝑡1t+1 must satisfy the consistency constraint that p0​zt+p1​zt=pz​0t+1+pz​1t+1subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡0𝑧subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡1𝑧subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡1𝑧0subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡1𝑧1p^{t}_{0z}+p^{t}_{1z}=p^{t+1}_{z0}+p^{t+1}_{z1}. To enforce this constraint, we introduce a correction term Δz=12​(p0​zt+p1​zt−(C^z​0t+1+C^z​1t+1))subscriptΔ𝑧12subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡0𝑧subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡1𝑧superscriptsubscript^𝐶𝑧0𝑡1superscriptsubscript^𝐶𝑧1𝑡1\Delta_{z}=\frac{1}{2}(p^{t}_{0z}+p^{t}_{1z}-(\hat{C}_{z0}^{t+1}+\hat{C}_{z1}^{t+1})), which depends on the synthetic data histogram at time t𝑡t, as well as the noisy DP histogram at time t+1𝑡1t+1. We set the target synthetic data counts to

pz​0t+1subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡1𝑧0\displaystyle p^{t+1}_{z0} =C^z​0t+1+Δzabsentsuperscriptsubscript^𝐶𝑧0𝑡1subscriptΔ𝑧\displaystyle=\hat{C}_{z0}^{t+1}+\Delta_{z} (1)
pz​1t+1subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡1𝑧1\displaystyle p^{t+1}_{z1} =C^z​1t+1+Δz.absentsuperscriptsubscript^𝐶𝑧1𝑡1subscriptΔ𝑧\displaystyle=\hat{C}_{z1}^{t+1}+\Delta_{z}. (2)

To generate synthetic data, the algorithm then extends pz​0t+1subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡1𝑧0p^{t+1}_{z0} records that ended in z𝑧z at time t𝑡t by the bit 00, and similarly, extends pz​1t+1subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡1𝑧1p^{t+1}_{z1} records ending in z𝑧z by 111. Note that the correction term ΔzsubscriptΔ𝑧\Delta_{z} may be a half-integer. If this is the case, we set

pz​0t+1subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡1𝑧0\displaystyle p^{t+1}_{z0} =C^z​0t+1+Δz+bzabsentsuperscriptsubscript^𝐶𝑧0𝑡1subscriptΔ𝑧subscript𝑏𝑧\displaystyle=\hat{C}_{z0}^{t+1}+\Delta_{z}+b_{z} (3)
pz​1t+1subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡1𝑧1\displaystyle p^{t+1}_{z1} =C^z​1t+1+Δz−bz,absentsuperscriptsubscript^𝐶𝑧1𝑡1subscriptΔ𝑧subscript𝑏𝑧\displaystyle=\hat{C}_{z1}^{t+1}+\Delta_{z}-b_{z}, (4)

where bzsubscript𝑏𝑧b_{z} is a rounding term which takes value −1212-\frac{1}{2} with probability 1212\frac{1}{2}, and 1212\frac{1}{2} with probability 1212\frac{1}{2}.

Note also that adding noise could result in negative numbers in the DP histograms, which is invalid for generating synthetic data. One possible way to address it is clamping the noisy counts to be non-negative, but this will break the consistency guarantee when continually releasing the synthetic data.

Instead, we introduce a padding technique to avoid the possibility of negative noisy counts by adding npadsubscript𝑛padn_{\text{pad}} “fake” people to each histogram bin at the very beginning. The appropriate choice of npadsubscript𝑛padn_{\text{pad}} depends on the privacy parameter, time horizon, and the target error probability βtargetsubscript𝛽target\beta_{\text{target}}. Intuitively, when adding npadsubscript𝑛padn_{\mathrm{pad}} “fake” people in each bin, a negative count still occurs if the noise random variable Yisubscript𝑌𝑖Y_{i} goes below −npadsubscript𝑛pad-n_{\mathrm{pad}}. This small error probability can be controlled by estimating the tail of the noise distribution. Since we are roughly adding discrete Gaussian noise with variance σ2=T−k+12​ρsuperscript𝜎2𝑇𝑘12𝜌\sigma^{2}=\frac{T-k+1}{2\rho}, we consider the maximal deviation of the independent noise draws over the 2k​(T−k+1)superscript2𝑘𝑇𝑘12^{k}(T-k+1) bins. We have Pr⁡(mini⁡Yi≤−npad)≤2k​(T−k+1)​exp⁡(−npad​ρT−k+1).Prsubscript𝑖subscript𝑌𝑖subscript𝑛padsuperscript2𝑘𝑇𝑘1subscript𝑛pad𝜌𝑇𝑘1\Pr(\min_{i}Y_{i}\leq-n_{\text{pad}})\leq 2^{k}(T-k+1)\exp\left(-\frac{n_{\text{pad}}\rho}{T-k+1}\right). Taking npad=T−k+1ρ​log⁡2k​(T−k+1)βtargetsubscript𝑛pad𝑇𝑘1𝜌superscript2𝑘𝑇𝑘1subscript𝛽targetn_{\text{pad}}=\sqrt{\frac{T-k+1}{\rho}\log\frac{2^{k}(T-k+1)}{\beta_{\text{target}}}} ensures that with probability at least 1−βtarget1subscript𝛽target1-\beta_{\text{target}}, the DP histograms for all T−k+1𝑇𝑘1T-k+1 update steps are all non-negative. Note that the more careful analysis of our algorithm also needs to account for the correction terms ΔΔ\Delta and rounding terms b𝑏b.

3.2 Theoretical guarantees

We now provide our theoretical analysis for Algorithm 1. We first argue its privacy and then describe the accuracy guarantee which measures the additive error of the fraction of every substring within a fixed window in the synthetic data.

Privacy.

Privacy of Algorithm 1 follows from composition of the noise-adding mechanism. The sensitivity of the count Cstsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝑡C_{s}^{t} is 111. Using the discrete Gaussian mechanism guarantees (ρT−k+1)𝜌𝑇𝑘1\left(\frac{\rho}{T-k+1}\right)-zCDP per update step. By composition for zCDP, we have ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP for the entire algorithm.

Theorem 3.1.

Algorithm 1 satisfies ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP.

Accuracy.

For each z∈{0,1}k−1𝑧superscript01𝑘1z\in\{0,1\}^{k-1} and c∈{0,1}𝑐01c\in\{0,1\}, denote the true count ending in z​c𝑧𝑐zc in the original data at time t𝑡t be Cz​ctsubscriptsuperscript𝐶𝑡𝑧𝑐C^{t}_{zc}. We are interested in controlling the additive deviation |p^z​ct−(Cz​ct+npad)|subscriptsuperscript^𝑝𝑡𝑧𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝐶𝑡𝑧𝑐subscript𝑛pad\lvert{\hat{p}^{t}_{zc}-(C^{t}_{zc}+n_{\text{pad}})}\rvert between the count of any given suffix in the synthetic data and the padded count from the original data. Perhaps surprisingly, we can maintain a time-uniform bound on the error with high probability. At a high level, we carefully characterize the exact noise propagation and show that the errors are mean 00 with the same variance over time. Then we can apply a Gaussian tail bound to analyze the error per histogram bin. An additional log⁡(2k​(T−k+1))superscript2𝑘𝑇𝑘1\log(2^{k}(T-k+1)) for the worst-case error comes from a union bound over at most 2k​(T−k+1)superscript2𝑘𝑇𝑘12^{k}(T-k+1) bins.

Theorem 3.2.

Let Cstsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝑡C_{s}^{t} be the true count of data records ending in s𝑠s at time step t𝑡t, and pstsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠𝑡p_{s}^{t} be the count in the synthetic data obtained by Algorithm 1. For every β∈(0,1)𝛽01\beta\in(0,1), with probability at least 1−β1𝛽1-\beta, the maximum additive error is bounded by

maxs,t⁡|pst−(Cst+npad)|≤(T−k+1ρ+12)​log⁡(2k​(T−k+1)β).subscript𝑠𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝐶𝑡𝑠subscript𝑛pad𝑇𝑘1𝜌12superscript2𝑘𝑇𝑘1𝛽\max_{s,t}\lvert{p^{t}_{s}-(C^{t}_{s}+n_{\mathrm{pad}})}\rvert\leq\left(\sqrt{\frac{T-k+1}{\rho}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)\sqrt{\log\left(\frac{2^{k}(T-k+1)}{\beta}\right)}. (5)

In particular, as long as npadsubscript𝑛padn_{\textrm{pad}} is at least the expression on the right-hand-side of (5), the noisy counts pstsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠𝑡p_{s}^{t} will all be non-negative and the algorithm will succeed at producing synthetic data.

When using the synthetic data we generate to answer a supported counting query q𝑞q, the padded records introduce bias to the resulting answers and degrade their worst-case error. However, note that the parameters npadsubscript𝑛padn_{\text{pad}} and k𝑘k are public. So an analyst with knowledge of these parameters can subtract the appropriate counts from q​(D^)𝑞^𝐷q(\hat{D}), which results in an unbiased estimate of the true count, and with lower worst-case error.

Proof of Theorem 3.2.

Let us briefly recall our quantities of interest and various intermediate quantities we generate along the way:

  1. 1.

    Cstsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝑡C_{s}^{t} is the true count of data records ending in s𝑠s at time step t𝑡t.

  2. 2.

    C¯st=Cst+npadsuperscriptsubscript¯𝐶𝑠𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝑡subscript𝑛pad\overline{C}_{s}^{t}=C_{s}^{t}+n_{\mathrm{pad}} is the true count on the padded dataset.

  3. 3.

    C^stsuperscriptsubscript^𝐶𝑠𝑡\hat{C}_{s}^{t} is the noisy count arising from the DP noisy histogram algorithm applied to the padded dataset.

  4. 4.

    pstsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠𝑡p_{s}^{t} is the corrected estimated count obtained using Equations 1 and 2.

To make the accuracy analysis easier to follow, we denote the total number of update steps of Algorithm 1 by R=T−k+1𝑅𝑇𝑘1R=T-k+1. Let us also index update steps by r=0,1,…,R−1𝑟01…𝑅1r=0,1,\dots,R-1, where update step r𝑟r occurs at time step t=r+k𝑡𝑟𝑘t=r+k.

Our algorithm uses the update rule stated in Equations 1 and 2, where Δz=12​(p0​zr+p1​zr−(C^z​0r+1+C^z​1r+1))subscriptΔ𝑧12subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑟0𝑧subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑟1𝑧superscriptsubscript^𝐶𝑧0𝑟1superscriptsubscript^𝐶𝑧1𝑟1\Delta_{z}=\frac{1}{2}(p^{r}_{0z}+p^{r}_{1z}-(\hat{C}_{z0}^{r+1}+\hat{C}_{z1}^{r+1})), for any r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1. This is equivalent to

pz​0r+1subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑟1𝑧0\displaystyle p^{r+1}_{z0} =12​C^z​0r+1+12​(p0​zr+p1​zr−C^z​1r+1)+bz⋅ezabsent12superscriptsubscript^𝐶𝑧0𝑟112subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑟0𝑧subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑟1𝑧superscriptsubscript^𝐶𝑧1𝑟1⋅subscript𝑏𝑧subscript𝑒𝑧\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2}\hat{C}_{z0}^{r+1}+\frac{1}{2}(p^{r}_{0z}+p^{r}_{1z}-\hat{C}_{z1}^{r+1})+b_{z}\cdot e_{z} (6)

We now analyze the variance of ΘrsuperscriptΘ𝑟\Theta^{r} by analyzing the contributions of the discrete Gaussian terms Xi,jsubscript𝑋𝑖𝑗X_{i,j} and the rounding terms Yi,j​Ei,jsubscript𝑌𝑖𝑗subscript𝐸𝑖𝑗Y_{i,j}E_{i,j} separately. Letting

which is the same regardless of the update step r𝑟r.

Denoting the contribution of the rounding terms by

We now combine the two sources of errors. Since Grsuperscript𝐺𝑟G^{r} and Brsuperscript𝐵𝑟B^{r} are (dependent) subgaussians with variances σ2=R/2​ρsuperscript𝜎2𝑅2𝜌\sigma^{2}=R/2\rho and 1/4141/4 respectively, their summation is subgaussian with variance (σ+1/2)2superscript𝜎122(\sigma+1/2)^{2} [Riv12]. Corollary 3.1.

Let β∈(0,1)𝛽01\beta\in(0,1) and npad=(T−k+1ρ+12)​log⁡(2k​(T−k+1)β)subscript𝑛pad𝑇𝑘1𝜌12superscript2𝑘𝑇𝑘1𝛽n_{\mathrm{pad}}=\left(\sqrt{\frac{T-k+1}{\rho}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)\sqrt{\log(\frac{2^{k}(T-k+1)}{\beta})}. With probability at least 1−β1𝛽1-\beta, the maximum relative error (with respect to the original counts Cstsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝑡C_{s}^{t}) is bounded by

maxs,t⁡|pstn∗−Cstn|≤(2k+1+2)​(T−k+1ρ+12)​log⁡(2k​(T−k+1)β)n=O​(2k​T​(k+log⁡(T/β))n​ρ).subscript𝑠𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑠superscript𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐶𝑡𝑠𝑛superscript2𝑘12𝑇𝑘1𝜌12superscript2𝑘𝑇𝑘1𝛽𝑛𝑂superscript2𝑘𝑇𝑘𝑇𝛽𝑛𝜌\max_{s,t}\left|\frac{p^{t}_{s}}{n^{*}}-\frac{C^{t}_{s}}{n}\right|\leq\dfrac{(2^{k+1}+2)\left(\sqrt{\frac{T-k+1}{\rho}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)\sqrt{\log\left(\frac{2^{k}(T-k+1)}{\beta}\right)}}{n}=O\left(\frac{2^{k}\sqrt{T(k+\log(T/\beta))}}{n\sqrt{\rho}}\right).
Proof.

For each s𝑠s and t𝑡t we may write

|pstn∗−Cstn|subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑠superscript𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐶𝑡𝑠𝑛\displaystyle\left|\frac{p^{t}_{s}}{n^{*}}-\frac{C^{t}_{s}}{n}\right| ≤|pstn∗−(Cst+npad)n∗|+npadn∗+|Cstn−Cstn∗|absentsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑠superscript𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐶𝑡𝑠subscript𝑛padsuperscript𝑛subscript𝑛padsuperscript𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐶𝑡𝑠𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐶𝑡𝑠superscript𝑛\displaystyle\leq\left|\frac{p^{t}_{s}}{n^{*}}-\frac{(C^{t}_{s}+n_{\mathrm{pad}})}{n^{*}}\right|+\frac{n_{\mathrm{pad}}}{n^{*}}+\left|\frac{C^{t}_{s}}{n}-\frac{C^{t}_{s}}{n^{*}}\right|

Let λ=(T−k+1ρ+12)​log⁡(2k​(T−k+1)β)𝜆𝑇𝑘1𝜌12superscript2𝑘𝑇𝑘1𝛽\lambda=\left(\sqrt{\frac{T-k+1}{\rho}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)\sqrt{\log(\frac{2^{k}(T-k+1)}{\beta})}. Then in particular, we have n≤n∗≤n+2k+1​λ𝑛superscript𝑛𝑛superscript2𝑘1𝜆n\leq n^{*}\leq n+2^{k+1}\lambda, which implies that for every s,t𝑠𝑡s,t, this expression is at most

∎

This statement gives an upper bound on the worst-case error of the synthetic dataset relative to the original dataset, but the answer is biased due to the padding. Note that if the analyst debiases each query answer, the maximum relative error is bounded by maxs,t⁡|(pst−npad)−Cst|n≤(T−k+1ρ+12)​log⁡(2k​(T−k+1)β)n.subscript𝑠𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑠subscript𝑛padsubscriptsuperscript𝐶𝑡𝑠𝑛𝑇𝑘1𝜌12superscript2𝑘𝑇𝑘1𝛽𝑛\max_{s,t}\frac{\lvert{(p^{t}_{s}-n_{\mathrm{pad}})-C^{t}_{s}}\rvert}{n}\leq\dfrac{\left(\sqrt{\frac{T-k+1}{\rho}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)\sqrt{\log\left(\frac{2^{k}(T-k+1)}{\beta}\right)}}{n}.

An interesting feature of the above analysis is that it makes some use of the distribution of errors introduced in the noisy histogram computation, rather than just a black-box upper bound on the magnitude of the error. Indeed, one could analyze accuracy by applying the triangle inequality to the magnitudes of these errors, but it would lead to worse error bounds. Suppose that at time t𝑡t, the noisy fractions in the synthetic data have additive error αtsubscript𝛼𝑡\alpha_{t}, that is, pz​0tsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑧0p^{t}_{z0} and pz​1tsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑧1p^{t}_{z1} satisfy |pz​0t−(Cz​0t+npad)|≤αtsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑧0subscriptsuperscript𝐶𝑡𝑧0subscript𝑛padsubscript𝛼𝑡\lvert{p^{t}_{z0}-(C^{t}_{z0}+n_{\text{pad}})}\rvert\leq\alpha_{t} and |pz​1t−(Cz​1t+npad)|≤αtsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑧1subscriptsuperscript𝐶𝑡𝑧1subscript𝑛padsubscript𝛼𝑡\lvert{p^{t}_{z1}-(C^{t}_{z1}+n_{\text{pad}})}\rvert\leq\alpha_{t}. Suppose the DP histogram at time t+1𝑡1t+1 introduces error of magnitude α𝛼\alpha, that is, |C^z​0t+1−(Cz​0t+1+npad)|≤αsuperscriptsubscript^𝐶𝑧0𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑧0𝑡1subscript𝑛pad𝛼\lvert{\hat{C}_{z0}^{t+1}-(C_{z0}^{t+1}+n_{\text{pad}})}\rvert\leq\alpha and |C^z​1t+1−(Cz​1t+1+npad)|≤αsuperscriptsubscript^𝐶𝑧1𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑧1𝑡1subscript𝑛pad𝛼\lvert{\hat{C}_{z1}^{t+1}-(C_{z1}^{t+1}+n_{\text{pad}})}\rvert\leq\alpha. For notational simplicity, let C¯st=Cst+npadsuperscriptsubscript¯𝐶𝑠𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝑡subscript𝑛pad\bar{C}_{s}^{t}=C_{s}^{t}+n_{\text{pad}}. Then we can bound the error in the synthetic data at time t+1𝑡1t+1 as follows.

By induction on t𝑡t, this analysis thus gives a worst-case error bound that grows linearly as time increases, i.e., proportional to T​α𝑇𝛼T\alpha where α𝛼\alpha is the magnitude of error introduced in a single round. In contrast, our analysis gives an error bound that does not grow with time, staying proportional just to α𝛼\alpha.

The weakness of the above error analysis justifies why we compute noisy histograms via simple independent noise addition, complemented by padding to maintain nonnegativity. While more sophisticated noisy histogram algorithms can achieve smaller error per round (and even nonnegativity by design), they do not seem able to match the final error guarantees of our algorithm. For example, one could try to use the stability-based histogram algorithm, as described in [BNS16], which achieves the relaxed notion of (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-differential privacy. This algorithm adds noise Lap​(1ε′)Lap1superscript𝜀′\text{Lap}(\frac{1}{\varepsilon^{\prime}}) only to the nonzero bins of the histogram, and then retains only the noisy values that are larger than the threshold Θ​(1ε′​log⁡(1δ))Θ1superscript𝜀′1𝛿\Theta(\frac{1}{\varepsilon^{\prime}}\log(\frac{1}{\delta})). It thus achieves error α=Θ​(1ε′​log⁡(1δ))𝛼Θ1superscript𝜀′1𝛿\alpha=\Theta(\frac{1}{\varepsilon^{\prime}}\log(\frac{1}{\delta})), independent of the number of bins, per round. By advanced composition, it suffices to set the per-round privacy budget to ε′=O​(ε/T)superscript𝜀′𝑂𝜀𝑇\varepsilon^{\prime}=O(\varepsilon/\sqrt{T}). Then following the naïve error analysis above, we would get that every noisy count in the synthetic data incurs error O​(T​Tε​log⁡(Tδ​β))𝑂𝑇𝑇𝜀𝑇𝛿𝛽O\left(\frac{T\sqrt{T}}{\varepsilon}\log(\frac{T}{\delta\beta})\right) with probability at least 1−β1𝛽1-\beta, which is worse than our upper bound by a factor of roughly T/2k𝑇superscript2𝑘T/2^{k}, while also achieving a weaker privacy definition.

4 Generating Synthetic Data for Cumulative Time Queries

In this section, we consider cumulative time queries, which track the Hamming weight of each individual’s history. Specifically, we would like the synthetic data to approximately preserve the fraction of people having at least b𝑏b 1’s in their data up to time t𝑡t, i.e., cbt​(D1,…,Dt)=1n​#​{i|xi1+xi2+…+xit≥b}superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑏𝑡superscript𝐷1…superscript𝐷𝑡1𝑛#conditional-set𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖2…superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡𝑏c_{b}^{t}(D^{1},\dots,D^{t})=\frac{1}{n}\#\{i|x_{i}^{1}+x_{i}^{2}+\ldots+x_{i}^{t}\geq b\} for t=1,2,…,T𝑡12…𝑇t=1,2,\ldots,T. In Section 2.1, we reduced cumulative time queries to fixed-time window queries. The worst-case error is O~​(T/n)~𝑂𝑇𝑛\widetilde{O}(T/n) when instantiating the algorithm for fixed-time window queries with k=T𝑘𝑇k=T. Here, we provide a CDP algorithm for this problem with a better accuracy guarantee of O~​(T/n)~𝑂𝑇𝑛\widetilde{O}(\sqrt{T}/n).

4.1 Preliminaries on Stream Counters

Our algorithm for cumulative time queries relies on the following important primitive from the literature on private continual release. A stream counter takes as input a stream of values z1,…,zTsuperscript𝑧1…superscript𝑧𝑇z^{1},\dots,z^{T}, where each ztsuperscript𝑧𝑡z^{t} is a natural number. At every time step t𝑡t, it releases an approximation S^tsuperscript^𝑆𝑡\hat{S}^{t} to the partial sum St=∑k=1tztsuperscript𝑆𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑡superscript𝑧𝑡S^{t}=\sum_{k=1}^{t}z^{t}. Two streams (z1,…,zT),((z1)′,…,(zT)′)superscript𝑧1…superscript𝑧𝑇superscriptsuperscript𝑧1′…superscriptsuperscript𝑧𝑇′(z^{1},\dots,z^{T}),((z^{1})^{\prime},\dots,(z^{T})^{\prime}) are neighbors if they differ in only one entry, and by magnitude 111 in that entry. That is, there exists an index t𝑡t such that |zt−(zt)′|≤1superscript𝑧𝑡superscriptsuperscript𝑧𝑡′1|z^{t}-(z^{t})^{\prime}|\leq 1 and zk=(zk)′superscript𝑧𝑘superscriptsuperscript𝑧𝑘′z^{k}=(z^{k})^{\prime} for all k≠t𝑘𝑡k\neq t. We are interested in stream counters whose sequence of outputs (S~1,…,S~T)superscript~𝑆1…superscript~𝑆𝑇(\widetilde{S}^{1},\dots,\widetilde{S}^{T}) guarantee ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP with respect to this neighboring relation. Moreover, we define accuracy for stream counters as follows.

Definition 4.1.

A stream counter is (α​(ρ,T),β​(ρ,T))𝛼𝜌𝑇𝛽𝜌𝑇(\alpha(\rho,T),\beta(\rho,T))-accurate if for every stream of length T𝑇T and every ρ𝜌\rho, it holds that

Pr⁡[|S~t−St|≤α​(ρ,T)]≥1−β​(ρ,T),Prsuperscript~𝑆𝑡superscript𝑆𝑡𝛼𝜌𝑇1𝛽𝜌𝑇\Pr[\lvert{\widetilde{S}^{t}-S^{t}}\rvert\leq\alpha(\rho,T)]\geq 1-\beta(\rho,T),

for every 1≤t≤T1𝑡𝑇1\leq t\leq T.

Note that in contrast to our definition of (α,β)𝛼𝛽(\alpha,\beta)-accuracy for synthetic data generation, here α​(ρ,T)𝛼𝜌𝑇\alpha(\rho,T) is generally in the range [0,T]0𝑇[0,T], i.e., it represents error with respect to counts rather than with respect to fractions.

The tree-based aggregation mechanism [DNPR10, CSS11] was the first implementation of a private stream counter. The algorithm works roughly as follows. Consider a complete binary tree, in which each leaf node is labeled by ztsuperscript𝑧𝑡z^{t} and represents the data arriving single time step. Each internal node tracks the sum of all leaves in its sub-tree. To ensure privacy, we add fresh discrete Gaussian noise with scale σ2=log⁡T/(2​ρ)superscript𝜎2𝑇2𝜌\sigma^{2}=\log T/(2\rho), denoted as 𝒩ℤ​(0,log⁡T/(2​ρ))subscript𝒩ℤ0𝑇2𝜌\mathcal{N}_{\mathbb{Z}}(0,\log T/(2\rho)) to each internal node. Because every time step only affects O​(log⁡T)𝑂𝑇O(\log T) nodes in this binary tree, the complete tree is ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP by composition.

Theorem 4.1.

The tree-based aggregation mechanism is ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP.

Every partial sum Stsuperscript𝑆𝑡S^{t} can be expressed as a sum of O​(log⁡t)𝑂𝑡O(\log t) nodes in this tree, and each such node introduces fresh noise 𝒩ℤ​(0,log⁡T/(2​ρ))subscript𝒩ℤ0𝑇2𝜌\mathcal{N}_{\mathbb{Z}}(0,\log T/(2\rho)). Therefore, the error for computing a private version of the partial sum |S~t−St|superscript~𝑆𝑡superscript𝑆𝑡\lvert{\widetilde{S}^{t}-S^{t}}\rvert is O​(log⁡Tρ​log⁡t)𝑂𝑇𝜌𝑡O(\sqrt{\frac{\log T}{\rho}}\sqrt{\log t}) with high probability. We formally describe the algorithm in Algorithm 2. (Note that the tree-based aggregation algorithm was initially described using Laplace noise, resulting a pure (ε,0)𝜀0(\varepsilon,0)-DP algorithm [DNPR10, CSS11].)

Theorem 4.2.

For each t=1,…,T𝑡1…𝑇t=1,\ldots,T individually, with probability at least 1−β1𝛽1-\beta, the error of the tree-based aggregation mechanism is bounded as follows:

|S~t−St|≤O​(log⁡Tρ⋅log⁡t⋅log⁡1β).superscript~𝑆𝑡superscript𝑆𝑡𝑂⋅𝑇𝜌𝑡1𝛽\lvert{\widetilde{S}^{t}-S^{t}}\rvert\leq O\left(\sqrt{\frac{\log T}{\rho}}\cdot\sqrt{\log t}\cdot\log\frac{1}{\beta}\right).

4.2 Algorithm

Our algorithm, presented formally in Algorithm 3, again consists of two phases: producing private statistics about the cumulative queries and constructing synthetic data according to the noisy statistics.

Producing noisy statistics.

Our algorithm relies on a stream counter mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M}, which takes in a stream of variables z1,z2,…,zTsuperscript𝑧1superscript𝑧2…superscript𝑧𝑇z^{1},z^{2},\ldots,z^{T} and produces a private estimate of the sum St=∑j=1tzjsuperscript𝑆𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑡superscript𝑧𝑗S^{t}=\sum_{j=1}^{t}z^{j} at each time t𝑡t. For each b=0,1,…,T𝑏01…𝑇b=0,1,\dots,T, we create an instance ℳbsubscriptℳ𝑏\mathcal{M}_{b} of the stream counter to track the number of people having at least b𝑏b 1’s up to time t𝑡t, denoted by Sbt=#​{i|xi1+xi2+…+xit≥b}superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡#conditional-set𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖2…superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡𝑏S_{b}^{t}=\#\{i|x_{i}^{1}+x_{i}^{2}+\ldots+x_{i}^{t}\geq b\} for each t=1,2,…,T𝑡12…𝑇t=1,2,\ldots,T. To see how to do this, let zbt=#{i|{xi1+…+xit−1=b−1 and xit=1}z_{b}^{t}=\#\{i|\{x_{i}^{1}+\ldots+x_{i}^{t-1}=b-1\text{ and }x^{t}_{i}=1\}, which denotes the number of people with exactly b−1𝑏1b-1 1’s up to time t−1𝑡1t-1, and also have a 111 at time t𝑡t. This allows us to represent Sbtsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡S_{b}^{t} as the sum Sbt=∑j=1tzbjsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑏𝑗S_{b}^{t}=\sum_{j=1}^{t}z_{b}^{j}. Note that for each value of b𝑏b, every user contributes at most one value of zbtsuperscriptsubscript𝑧𝑏𝑡z_{b}^{t}. This ensures that neighboring datasets induce neighboring streams for each stream counter. In Section 5, we instantiate the stream counter using the tree-based aggregation mechanism in our experiments.

The true counts (Sb1,…,SbT)superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏1…superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑇(S_{b}^{1},\dots,S_{b}^{T}) are monotonically increasing because each zbtsuperscriptsubscript𝑧𝑏𝑡z_{b}^{t} is nonnegative. But adding noise for privacy may violate the monotonicity of the stream. Maintaining monotonicity is essential for ensuring the existence of consistent synthetic data in the next phase. To ensure monotonicity, we maintain a monotonized stream as follows. In each time step t𝑡t, let S~btsuperscriptsubscript~𝑆𝑏𝑡\tilde{S}_{b}^{t} be the output of the stream counter ℳbsubscriptℳ𝑏\mathcal{M}_{b}. Set the output S^btsuperscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡\hat{S}_{b}^{t} of the monotonized counter to be S^bt=min⁡{max⁡{S~bt,S^bt−1},S^b−1t−1}superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript~𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡1superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏1𝑡1\hat{S}_{b}^{t}=\min\{\max\{\tilde{S}_{b}^{t},\hat{S}_{b}^{t-1}\},\hat{S}_{b-1}^{t-1}\}, i.e., clamp it so that S^bt−1≤S^bt≤S^b−1t−1superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡1superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏1𝑡1\hat{S}_{b}^{t-1}\leq\hat{S}_{b}^{t}\leq\hat{S}_{b-1}^{t-1}. We require the upper bound S^bt≤S^b−1t−1superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏1𝑡1\hat{S}_{b}^{t}\leq\hat{S}_{b-1}^{t-1} because the number of people having b𝑏b 1’s up to time t𝑡t cannot exceed the number of people having b−1𝑏1b-1 1’s up to time t−1𝑡1t-1. A similar idea for maintaining consistency for a single stream counter was shown in [CSS11] not to increase the error in any of the counts produced. Our generalization of this fact shows that it continues to hold even when we require a natural monotonicity constraint across different invocations of the stream counter.

Generating synthetic data.

By post-processing, we may also privately reveal the statistics z^bt=S^bt−S^bt−1superscriptsubscript^𝑧𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡1\hat{z}_{b}^{t}=\hat{S}_{b}^{t}-\hat{S}_{b}^{t-1}. At time t𝑡t, we update the synthetic dataset to maintain consistency with z^btsuperscriptsubscript^𝑧𝑏𝑡\hat{z}_{b}^{t} for every b=1,…,t𝑏1…𝑡b=1,\ldots,t. To be concrete, at time t𝑡t, for the set of indices {i∣x^i1+…+x^it−1=b−1}conditional-set𝑖superscriptsubscript^𝑥𝑖1…superscriptsubscript^𝑥𝑖𝑡1𝑏1\{i\mid\hat{x}_{i}^{1}+\ldots+\hat{x}_{i}^{t-1}=b-1\}, the algorithm extends z^btsuperscriptsubscript^𝑧𝑏𝑡\hat{z}_{b}^{t} rows by 111, and the remaining S^b−1t−1−S^btsuperscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏1𝑡1superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡\hat{S}_{b-1}^{t-1}-\hat{S}_{b}^{t} rows by 0. This is possible because the monotonization procedure described above ensures that z^bt≥0superscriptsubscript^𝑧𝑏𝑡0\hat{z}_{b}^{t}\geq 0 and S^b−1t−1−S^bt≥0superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏1𝑡1superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡0\hat{S}_{b-1}^{t-1}-\hat{S}_{b}^{t}\geq 0.

4.3 Theoretical guarantees

Privacy.

The privacy of Algorithm 3 follows from the composition of T𝑇T stream counters.

Theorem 4.3.

Algorithm 3 satisfies ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP.

Accuracy.

Our algorithm monotonizes the stream of counters to be S^bt=min⁡{max⁡{S~bt,S^bt−1},S^b−1t−1}superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript~𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡1superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏1𝑡1\hat{S}_{b}^{t}=\min\{\max\{\tilde{S}_{b}^{t},\hat{S}_{b}^{t-1}\},\hat{S}_{b-1}^{t-1}\}. Our proof relies on Lemma 4.4 showing that the error of the monotonized counter is at most that of ordinary stream counter, so this step will not incur additional error.

We first show in Lemma 4.4 that the error of the monotonized counter is at most that of ordinary stream counter, so this step will not incur additional error.

Lemma 4.4.

Let the true count at time t𝑡t be Sbt=#​{i|xi1+xi2+…+xit≥b}superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡#conditional-set𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖2…superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡𝑏S_{b}^{t}=\#\{i|x_{i}^{1}+x_{i}^{2}+\ldots+x_{i}^{t}\geq b\}, the noisy count be S~btsuperscriptsubscript~𝑆𝑏𝑡\tilde{S}_{b}^{t}, and the monotonized noisy count be S^btsuperscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡\hat{S}_{b}^{t}. For every t=1,2,…,T𝑡12…𝑇t=1,2,\ldots,T, and every b=1,2,…,t𝑏12…𝑡b=1,2,\ldots,t, we have

|S^bt−Sbt|≤max⁡{|S~bt−Sbt|,|S^bt−1−Sbt−1|,|S^b−1t−1−Sb−1t−1|}.superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript~𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡1superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏1𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏1𝑡1\lvert{\hat{S}_{b}^{t}-S_{b}^{t}}\rvert\leq\max\{\lvert{\tilde{S}_{b}^{t}-S_{b}^{t}}\rvert,\lvert{\hat{S}_{b}^{t-1}-S_{b}^{t-1}}\rvert,\lvert{\hat{S}_{b-1}^{t-1}-S_{b-1}^{t-1}}\rvert\}. (10)

For b=0𝑏0b=0,

|S^bt−Sbt|≤max⁡{|S~bt−Sbt|,|S^bt−1−Sbt−1|}.superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript~𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡1\lvert{\hat{S}_{b}^{t}-S_{b}^{t}}\rvert\leq\max\{\lvert{\tilde{S}_{b}^{t}-S_{b}^{t}}\rvert,\lvert{\hat{S}_{b}^{t-1}-S_{b}^{t-1}}\rvert\}. Proof.

The proof of Lemma 4.4 relies on the following simple inequality.

Claim 4.5.

For real numbers A,B,C,D𝐴𝐵𝐶𝐷A,B,C,D, if A≤B𝐴𝐵A\leq B, and D≤C𝐷𝐶D\leq C, then

|B−C|≤max⁡{|A−C|,|B−D|}.𝐵𝐶𝐴𝐶𝐵𝐷\lvert{B-C}\rvert\leq\max\{\lvert{A-C}\rvert,\lvert{B-D}\rvert\}.

We first prove this claim. Fix A𝐴A and B𝐵B. Depending on C𝐶C, we consider the following three cases. When A≤B≤C𝐴𝐵𝐶A\leq B\leq C, |B−C|≤|A−C|𝐵𝐶𝐴𝐶\lvert{B-C}\rvert\leq\lvert{A-C}\rvert. When C≤A≤B𝐶𝐴𝐵C\leq A\leq B, |B−C|≤|B−D|𝐵𝐶𝐵𝐷\lvert{B-C}\rvert\leq\lvert{B-D}\rvert. When A≤C≤B𝐴𝐶𝐵A\leq C\leq B, |B−C|≤|B−D|𝐵𝐶𝐵𝐷\lvert{B-C}\rvert\leq\lvert{B-D}\rvert holds regardless of where D𝐷D is relative to A𝐴A, so we complete the proof for this claim.

Lemma 4.4 proceeds from Claim 4.5, which can be seen as follows. When S^bt=S~btsuperscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript~𝑆𝑏𝑡\hat{S}_{b}^{t}=\tilde{S}_{b}^{t}, then accuracy follows from that of the ordinary stream counter. Thus we only need to consider the two cases where S^bt=S^bt−1superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡1\hat{S}_{b}^{t}=\hat{S}_{b}^{t-1} or S^bt=S^b−1t−1superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏1𝑡1\hat{S}_{b}^{t}=\hat{S}_{b-1}^{t-1}. For the first case where S^bt=S^bt−1superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡1\hat{S}_{b}^{t}=\hat{S}_{b}^{t-1}, we have S~bt≤S^btsuperscriptsubscript~𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡\tilde{S}_{b}^{t}\leq\hat{S}_{b}^{t} by the construction of S^btsuperscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡\hat{S}_{b}^{t}, and Sbt−1≤Sbtsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡S_{b}^{t-1}\leq S_{b}^{t} because of the monotonicity of Sbtsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡S_{b}^{t}. Instantiating Claim 4.5 with A=S~bt𝐴superscriptsubscript~𝑆𝑏𝑡A=\tilde{S}_{b}^{t}, B=S^bt𝐵superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡B=\hat{S}_{b}^{t}, C=Sbt𝐶superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡C=S_{b}^{t}, and D=Sbt−1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡1D=S_{b}^{t-1}, we have

|S^bt−Sbt|≤max{|S~bt−Sbt|,|S^bt−Sbt−1|=max{|S~bt−Sbt|,|S^bt−1−Sbt−1|}.\lvert{\hat{S}_{b}^{t}-S_{b}^{t}}\rvert\leq\max\{\lvert{\tilde{S}_{b}^{t}-S_{b}^{t}}\rvert,\lvert{\hat{S}_{b}^{t}-S_{b}^{t-1}}\rvert=\max\{\lvert{\tilde{S}_{b}^{t}-S_{b}^{t}}\rvert,\lvert{\hat{S}_{b}^{t-1}-S_{b}^{t-1}}\rvert\}. (12)

Similarly, for the second case where S^bt=S^b−1t−1superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏1𝑡1\hat{S}_{b}^{t}=\hat{S}_{b-1}^{t-1}, we have S~bt≥S^bt=S^b−1t−1superscriptsubscript~𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏1𝑡1\tilde{S}_{b}^{t}\geq\hat{S}_{b}^{t}=\hat{S}_{b-1}^{t-1} by the construction of S^btsuperscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡\hat{S}_{b}^{t}, and Sb−1t−1≥Sbtsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏1𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡S_{b-1}^{t-1}\geq S_{b}^{t} because of the monotonicity of Sbtsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡S_{b}^{t}. We then instantiate Claim 4.5 with A=−S~bt𝐴superscriptsubscript~𝑆𝑏𝑡A=-\tilde{S}_{b}^{t}, B=−S^b−1t−1𝐵superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏1𝑡1B=-\hat{S}_{b-1}^{t-1}, C=−Sbt𝐶superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡C=-S_{b}^{t} and D=−Sb−1t−1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏1𝑡1D=-S_{b-1}^{t-1}. and we have

|S^b−1t−1−Sbt|≤max⁡{|S~bt−Sbt|,|S^b−1t−1−Sb−1t−1|}.superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏1𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript~𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏1𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏1𝑡1\lvert{\hat{S}_{b-1}^{t-1}-S_{b}^{t}}\rvert\leq\max\{\lvert{\tilde{S}_{b}^{t}-S_{b}^{t}}\rvert,\lvert{\hat{S}_{b-1}^{t-1}-S_{b-1}^{t-1}}\rvert\}. (13)

Since S^bt=S^b−1t−1superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏1𝑡1\hat{S}_{b}^{t}=\hat{S}_{b-1}^{t-1},  (13) is equivalent to

|S^bt−Sbt|≤max⁡{|S~bt−Sbt|,|S^b−1t−1−Sb−1t−1|}.superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript~𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝑆𝑏1𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑏1𝑡1\lvert{\hat{S}_{b}^{t}-S_{b}^{t}}\rvert\leq\max\{\lvert{\tilde{S}_{b}^{t}-S_{b}^{t}}\rvert,\lvert{\hat{S}_{b-1}^{t-1}-S_{b-1}^{t-1}}\rvert\}. (14)

Combining (12) and (14), we obtain (10), completing the proof. ∎

Lemma 4.4 implies that the worst-case error of Algorithm 3 is at most the worst-case error of T𝑇T stream counters, normalized by the dataset size n𝑛n.

Theorem 4.6.

When instantiated with an (α,β)𝛼𝛽(\alpha,\beta)-accurate stream counter ℳℳ\mathcal{M}, Algorithm 3 is (α∗,β∗)superscript𝛼superscript𝛽(\alpha^{*},\beta^{*})-accurate for α∗=1n​maxb⁡α​(ρb,T−b+1)superscript𝛼1𝑛subscript𝑏𝛼subscript𝜌𝑏𝑇𝑏1\alpha^{*}=\frac{1}{n}\max_{b}\alpha\left(\rho_{b},T-b+1\right) and β∗=∑b=1Tβ​(ρb,T−b+1).superscript𝛽superscriptsubscript𝑏1𝑇𝛽subscript𝜌𝑏𝑇𝑏1\beta^{*}=\sum_{b=1}^{T}\beta(\rho_{b},T-b+1).

4.3.1 Instantiation using the tree-based aggregation mechanism

We now state the accuracy guarantee when we instantiate the tree-based aggregation mechanism as the stream counter ℳℳ\mathcal{M}. For the b𝑏b-th tree-based counter, we add 𝒩ℤ​(0,σb2)subscript𝒩ℤ0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑏2\mathcal{N}_{\mathbb{Z}}(0,\sigma_{b}^{2}) to the internal nodes. 5 Experiments

In this section, we study the empirical performance of the algorithms introduced in this paper. We show how the algorithms perform with a real data application and apply our algorithms to data from the Survey of Income and Program Participation (SIPP) by the U.S. Census Bureau [Bur21]. Unless otherwise stated, we use noise-adding mechanisms with the variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} calibrated to achieve overall 0.0050.0050.005-zCDP. Code to replicate the experiments is part of the Supporting Information of this paper.

Simulated Data.

First, we evaluate Algorithm 1 on rather extreme simulated data. We set the number of observations n𝑛n to 250002500025000 and the time horizon T𝑇T to 121212. We choose these values to demonstrate typical data sizes in longitudinal studies (e.g., 250002500025000 survey respondents with monthly measurements for one year). In the extreme setting, all data updates are set to 111. We then generate synthetic data to preserve fixed-time window queries using a window size k𝑘k of 333 (e.g., to reflect an interest in quarterly statistics).

Figure 1 summarizes the results of 100010001000 repeated runs of Algorithm 1. In the top panel of Figure 1, we show the (desired) scenario where the fixed window size k𝑘k specified to the synthesizer coincides with the window size of the query we are evaluating. As predicted by Theorem 3.2, the empirical error remains constant across time. In the middle panel, we highlight an advantage of releasing synthetic and padding data. Since all fixed time window queries with a window size at most k𝑘k of the synthesizer can be written as a low-weight linear combination of width-k𝑘k queries, the synthesized data remains accurate for these queries as well. Finally, we display what happens if the window size of the query exceeds k𝑘k of the synthesizer. Given our algorithm, we do not expect the synthetic data to preserve queries of longer window sizes. Indeed, we can observe that the empirical error increases substantially. We suggest that this warrants a word of caution for synthetic data analysts: Only queries supported by the synthesizer can be answered accurately. We cannot expect reasonable accuracy guarantees for queries not specifically supported by the synthesizer.

In Figure 2, we show that the debiasing step is essential. Calculating the proportions on the synthetic data directly leads to a substantially larger error.

Real Data Application: Releasing Poverty Rates from the Survey of Income and Program Participation (SIPP).

We now turn to an application of Algorithm 1 to data collected in the SIPP [Bur21]. We downloaded the 2021 sample from https://www2.census.gov/programs-surveys/sipp/data/datasets/2021/pu2021_csv.zip and detail the pre-processing steps in the Appendix. We aim to estimate the proportion of households in the SIPP data that are in poverty.

We need to take a couple of data pre-processing steps to get the SIPP data into shape for our data synthesizer. First, in the SIPP data, it is possible that multiple persons per household are surveyed. Thus, we first subset the data to one longitudinal series per household. The SIPP variable ‘THINCPOVT2’ is coded as the household income ratio to the household poverty threshold in a given month. We binarize this such that any values of the ratio smaller than one are coded as 111 (indicating that a household was in poverty in a given month). Finally, some households have missing values. We delete every household that has at least one missing value. Our final SIPP data sample consists of 233742337423374 households (N=23374𝑁23374N=23374) with 121212 monthly measurements (T=12𝑇12T=12) for 2021 that indicate whether a household was in poverty in a given month. For our experiment, we treat this SIPP sample as ground truth. This means our goal is to accurately estimate the proportion of households in poverty in the SIPP sample. This differs from making inferences about a larger population (from which the sample was drawn). We leave it to future work to integrate DP longitudinal synthetic data with inferential statistics and to compare the magnitude of sampling noise to the magnitude of the privacy noise. Furthermore, we focus on one particular poverty indicator, “Household income-to-poverty ratio in this month, including Type 2 individuals”.

Synthetic data for fixed time window queries.

We then synthesize the SIPP sample with a fixed window size of 3 (k=3𝑘3k=3) to reflect quarterly measurements and repeat the synthesizer 100010001000 times. We present the results in Panel of Figures 4-5 for different values of the privacy parameter ρ𝜌\rho. To estimate the proportion of households in poverty in a given quarter, it is natural to examine four different quantities. First, the proportion of households in poverty for at least one month of the quarter. Second, is the proportion of households in poverty for at least two months of the quarter. Third, the proportion of households in poverty for at least two consecutive months of the quarter. And fourth, the proportion of households in poverty for all three months of the quarter. A major advantage of our synthetic data approach is that we can answer any such query written as a linear combination of histogram queries (with a fixed window size of at most k𝑘k) without any additional privacy cost. In the right panels of Figures 3-5, we show that our approach leads to unbiased estimates of the quantities (by subtracting the query answer on the padding data from the query answer on the complete synthetic data) with good accuracy. In the left panels of Figures 3-5, we show that ignoring the debiasing step can lead to substantial bias.

Synthetic data based on cumulative time queries.

Finally, we show how to release DP synthetic data from Algorithm 3. With the DP synthetic data based on cumulative time queries, we can answer queries like “how many households were at least three months in poverty in any given month”. In Figure 6, we show that these queries can be accurately answered using the DP synthetic data based on cumulative time queries.While Algorithm 3 generates synthetic data for all time thresholds b𝑏b from 1,…,T1…𝑇1,\dots,T simultaneously, we here focus on the results for setting the threshold to b=3𝑏3b=3.

In Figure 7 we show the empirical error distribution across 100010001000 repeated applications of our algorithm on the SIPP data and compare it to the worst-case error presented in Corollary 4.1.
